chapter.title: Installation of Additional Services
chapter.para: After you deploy your &storage; cluster you may need to install additional software for accessing your data —&rgw; or the iSCSI Gateway, or you can deploy a clustered file system on top of the &ceph; cluster. This chapter mainly focuses on installation on clusters deployed with ceph-deploy, if you have a cluster deployed by using &salt;, refer to the for a procedure of installing particular gateways or the &cephfs;.

sect1.title: &rgw; Installation
sect1.para: There are two possible ways how you can install &rgw; —by using ceph-deploy or manually by using zypper.

sect2.title: &rgw; Installation via ceph-deploy

sect2.title: &rgw; Configuration
sect2.para: Several steps are required to configure a &rgw;.

note.title: Configuration after Manual Installation
note.para: If you installed &rgw; by using ceph-deploy, you don't have to configure &rgw; as it is done automatically.

sect3.title: Basic Configuration

listitem.para: A host name for the gateway instance, for example gateway.
A storage cluster user name with appropriate permissions and a keyring.
A data directory for the gateway instance.
An instance entry in the &ceph; Configuration file.

sect3.para: Each instance must have a user name and key to communicate with a &ceph; storage cluster. In the following steps, we use a monitor node to create a bootstrap keyring, then create the &rgw; instance user keyring based on the bootstrap one. Then, we create a client user name and key. Next, we add the key to the &ceph; Storage Cluster. Finally, we distribute the keyring to the node containing the gateway instance.

step.para: Create a keyring for the gateway:
Generate a &ceph; &rgw; user name and key for each instance. As an example, we will use the name gateway after client.radosgw:

step.screen: sudo ceph-authtool -n client.rgw.gateway --cap osd 'allow rwx' \ --cap mon 'allow rwx' /etc/ceph/ceph.client.rgw.keyring

step.para: Once you have created a keyring and key to enable the &ceph; Object Gateway with access to the &ceph; Storage Cluster, add the key to your &ceph; Storage Cluster. For example:
Distribute the keyring to the node with the gateway instance:
step.screen: sudo scp /etc/ceph/ceph.client.rgw.keyring ceph@hostname:/home/ceph ssh hostname sudo mv ceph.client.rgw.keyring /etc/ceph/ceph.client.rgw.keyring

tip.title: Use Bootstrap Keyring
tip.para: An alternative way is to create the &rgw; bootstrap keyring, and then create the &rgw; keyring from it:

step.para: Create a &rgw; bootstrap keyring on one of the monitor nodes:
step.screen: sudo ceph \ auth get-or-create client.bootstrap-rgw mon 'allow profile bootstrap-rgw' \ --connect-timeout=25 \ --cluster=ceph \ --name mon. \ --keyring=/var/lib/ceph/mon/ceph-node_host/keyring \ -o /var/lib/ceph/bootstrap-rgw/keyring

step.para: Create the /var/lib/ceph/radosgw/ceph-rgw_name directory for storing the bootstrap keyring:
Create a &rgw; keyring from the newly created bootstrap keyring:
step.screen: sudo ceph \ auth get-or-create client.rgw.rgw_name osd 'allow rwx' mon 'allow rw' \ --connect-timeout=25 \ --cluster=ceph \ --name client.bootstrap-rgw \ --keyring=/var/lib/ceph/bootstrap-rgw/keyring \ -o /var/lib/ceph/radosgw/ceph-rgw_name/keyring

sect3.title: Create Pools (Optional)
sect3.para: &ceph; &rgw;s require &ceph; Storage Cluster pools to store specific gateway data. If the user you created has proper permissions, the gateway will create the pools automatically. However, ensure that you have set an appropriate default number of placement groups per pool in the &ceph; configuration file.
When configuring a gateway with the default region and zone, the naming convention for pools typically uses 'default' for region and zone naming, but you can use any naming convention you prefer:
sect3.screen: .rgw.root default.rgw.control default.rgw.data.root default.rgw.gc default.rgw.log default.rgw.users.uid default.rgw.users.email default.rgw.users.keys default.rgw.meta default.rgw.users.swift
